## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> handle that poisons itself if the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> is deleted.

This is a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> Handle that points to a value and poisons itself if the value is destroyed while the handle is still live. This is very useful for catching dangling pointer bugs where an <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/assertingvh">AssertingVH</a></code> cannot be used because the dangling handle needs to outlive the value without ever being used.

One particularly useful place to use this is as the Key of a map. Dangling pointer bugs often lead to really subtle bugs that only occur if another object happens to get allocated to the same address as the old one. Using a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/poisoningvh">PoisoningVH</a> ensures that an assert is triggered if looking up a new value in the map finds a handle from the old value.

Note that a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/poisoningvh">PoisoningVH</a> handle does <em>not</em> follow values across RAUW operations. This means that RAUW&#39;s need to explicitly update the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/poisoningvh">PoisoningVH</a>&#39;s as it moves. This is required because in non-assert mode this class turns into a trivial wrapper around a pointer.

Definition at line 445 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/valuehandle-h">ValueHandle.h</a>.
